metadata.title: Links between peptides and Mn oxide: nano-sized manganese oxide embedded in a peptide matrix

sections.text:
This journal is©The Royal Society of Chemistry and the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique 2018 New J. Chem., 2018, 42, 10067--10077 | 10067
Cite this: NewJ.Chem., 2018, 42, 10067
Links between peptides and Mn oxide: nano-sized manganese oxide embedded in a peptide matrix†
Mohammad Mahdi Najafpour, *abc Sepideh Madadkhani,a Somayyeh Akbarian,a Zahra Zand,a Małgorzata Hołyńska,d Mohsen Kompany-Zareh, ab Tomo Tatsuya, e Jitendra Pal Singh, f Keun Hwa Chaef and Suleyman I. Allakhverdiev *ghijk
Herein we report on a poly-peptide/Mn oxide nanocomposite as a model for the water-oxidizing catalyst
in Photosystem II. The material is obtained by the reaction of poly-L-tyrosine, Mn(OAc)2 4H2O and KMnO4. HRTEM images of the nanocomposite indicate the presence of nanoparticles dispersed in a poly-Ltyrosine matrix with no crystalline phases. A broad peak at B400–550 nm in the UV-visible spectrum is
related to Mn oxide formation. X-ray absorption studies suggest that the Mn atoms are in the oxidation
state of +IV and a coordination number of around three was obtained for Mn in the structure. The water-
oxidizing activity of the material under electrochemical conditions was also investigated. Electrochemical
experiments proved the presence of Mn(IV) oxide. Determination of oxygen coupled to electrochemistry
revealed the role of poly-L-tyrosine in decreasing the overpotential for water oxidation. In the next step,
the interaction of the nanocomposite and imidazole as a model for the tyrosine 161 and histidine 190
residues in Photosystem II was studied with fluorescence spectroscopy using the multivariate curve
resolution-alternating least squares method.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
In Nature, the water-oxidizing complex (WOC), being part of Photosystem II (PSII), is an efficient system that can catalyze water oxidation. PSII is a protein complex embedded in the thylakoid membranes of plant chloroplasts.1–4
In PSII, upon absorption of light energy, one of the chlorophyll molecules (Chls; the coupled state of ChlD1 and the Chl dimer P680) becomes excited and donates an electron to the pheophytin (Pheo) electron acceptor, resulting in a charge-separated state, P680+ Pheo .2–4 P680+ is reduced by an electron from the amino acid tyrosine, Tyr161 of the D1 subunit, designated as YZ. YZ is reduced by an electron originating from the WOC.5–8
The Mn4CaO5 cluster is coordinated by four water molecules, one imidazole ligand and six carboxylate groups of the amino acid residues. The high-resolution PSII structure revealed that W3 and W4 are coordinated to the Ca2+ ion. The water molecules (W4 and W3) are directly and indirectly hydrogen-bonded to YZ. The hydrogen bonds are also important in mediating of the electron transfer between the Mn4CaO5 cluster and the chlorophyll molecules of the PSII reaction center (Scheme 1(a)).9–11
When YZ is oxidized by P680 +, the phenolic group becomes very acidic (pKa B 2)15 and is deprotonated to form a neutral YZ radical (Scheme 1(b)).
12–18 As shown in Scheme 1, the proton acceptor is the nitrogen atom of the imidazole group of the D1-His190 residue which is hydrogen-bonded to the

phenolic proton. The X-ray structure of PSII at a resolution of 1.9 Å exhibited a remarkably short distance of 2.46 Å between the YZ oxygen and the nitrogen atoms of D1-His190. This hydrogen bond is very important for the electron transfer from the WOC to P680.19
In the investigation of the tyrosine-histidine-based protoncoupled electron transfer (PCET), electron-transfer (ET) and proton transfer, a wide variety of useful model compounds and biomimetic approaches have been reported. For example, the proton transferred from the YZ to the D1-His190 residue can be detected using light-induced Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR).20–25
Design of synthetic models able to mimic the proton-coupled electron transfer between the P680 and the YZ-D1-H190 pair of PSII is a challenging step in the development of artificial photosynthetic devices.26–38 The research groups of Aukauloo, Thomas and Moore used 2-(2-hydroxyphenyl)-1H-benzimidazole phenol as a model for Tyrz-D1-H190 in PSII.
29,39 2-(2-Hydroxyphenyl)-1Hbenzimidazole phenol between the layers of manganese(III, IV) oxide as an artificial model for YZ and D1-H190 near the manganese cluster in the PSII was also reported.40
As mentioned above, in PSII, the Mn4CaO5 cluster is the only known system to catalyze water oxidation in Nature. Many manganese compounds have been synthesized by different groups with the aim of mimicking the WOC of PSII. Among different Mn compounds41–45 Mn oxides are known as stable and good biomimetic model catalysts for water oxidation.46–50
A few groups, with the goal of copying the WOC of PSII, reported that treatment of Mn oxide with organic compounds reduced the overpotential of the catalyst for water oxidation.51–56
Herein, we synthesized an Mn oxide/poly-L-tyrosine nanocomposite to explore the interaction between the Mn oxide and tyrosine. In the next step, using imidazole as a model for the YZ/D1-H190 couple, near the manganese cluster in PSII, we also studied the interaction between the tested material and imidazole.

sections.heading: Materials and methods
sections.text:
Reagents poly-L-tyrosine (10 000–40 000 (wt)) (Sigma-Aldrich Company); Mn(OAc)2 4H2O (Sigma-Aldrich Company); KMnO4 (Merck Company) and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification. Water oxidation experiments in the presence of Ce(IV) were performed using an HQ40d portable dissolved oxygen meter connected to an oxygen monitor with a digital readout at 25 1C. Poly-Ltyrosine (10 000–40 000 (wt)) (Scheme 2) was purchased from the Sigma-Aldrich Company. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) images were taken using REM JEOL JSM-7500F and JEM-3010 UHR (JEOL Ltd, Japan, equipped with a retractable high-resolution slow scan CCD-Camera with a GOS phosphorous scintillator and lanthanum hexaboride cathode as the electron source) devices, respectively. Electrochemical experiments were performed using an EmStat3+ device from the PalmSens Company (The Netherlands). Fluorescence spectra were recorded on a Cary Eclipse Spectrofluorometer. The fluorescence Excitation–Emission Matrix (EEM) profiles were obtained by recording the emission spectra from 250 to 500 nm (every 2 nm) at excitation wavelengths ranging from 200 to 400 nm (every 5 nm). Also, the excitation and emission slits were set at 5 nm and the scan rate was at 1200 nm min 1. All these measurements were carried out at room temperature (26 0.5 1C).
Multivariate curve resolution method
The multivariate curve resolution-alternating least squares (MCRALS) method is based on a bilinear model which adjudges that the related spectra are a linear combination of the spectra of the pure components in the considered system.59 It decomposes the data matrix, D into two matrices, one including pure concentration profiles, C, the other including spectral profiles, ST. There are various components in the data matrix of the system under investigation. The product, CST, reconstructs the main data matrix, D and according to eqn (1) the residual error, E, is minimized:
D = CST + E (1)

sections.heading: Synthesis of 1 and 2
sections.text:
1. The nanosized Mn oxide/poly-L-tyrosine nano(1) was synthesized using a simple method. To a solution of poly-L-tyrosine (Schemes 2, 20.0 mg) in water (10 mL), Mn(OAc)2 4H2O (6.0 mg) was added and the resulting nanocomposite was stirred for 1 h. Then, a solution of KMnO4 (1.8 mg) in water (2 mL) containing Ca(OH)2 (pH = 10) was added at 4 1C and stirred for 30 minutes. The resulting solution was used for characterization.
2. To a solution of poly-L-tyrosine (Schemes 2, 40.0 mg) in water (10 mL), Mn(OAc)2 4H2O (6.0 mg) was added and stirred for 1 h. Then, a solution of KMnO4 (1.8 mg) in water (2 mL) containing Ca(OH)2 (pH = 10) was added at 4 1C and stirred for 30 minutes. The resulting solution was used for characterization.
Mn oxide. This was prepared using the same method as for 1 or 2 but without the use of poly-L-tyrosine.

sections.heading: Fabrication of a modified electrode
sections.text: FTO (Fluorine-doped Tin Oxide) was directly used as an electrode. A 20 mL suspension of 1 was dripped onto the FTO electrode surface and dried at room temperature. Eventually, 10 mL of 0.5 wt% Nafion solution was deposited onto the center of the modified electrode. Nafion is a sulfonated tetrafluoroethylene-based fluoropolymer and is among the first synthesized polymers with ionic conductivity. The small particles of the nanocomposites were incorporated onto the FTO electrode by Nafion. Cyclic voltammetry studies were carried out with a conventional three-electrode setup in which FTO, Ag|AgCl|KClsat and platinum foil served as the working, reference and auxiliary electrodes, respectively.

sections.heading: X-ray absorption experiments
sections.text:
The extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) measurements for 2, layered Mn oxide53d and the reference oxides (MnO, Mn2O3, MnO2) were performed at the hard X-ray 1D XRS KIST-PAL beamline (Pohang Accelerator Laboratory PAL) operating at 3.0 GeV with a maximum storage current of 300 mA. This beamline comprises a bending magnet and an X-ray Scattering (XRS) beamline which uses an Si(111) double crystal monochromator to give a wide range of radiation energies (4–16 keV).
To measure the EXAFS spectra of these materials, higher harmonics were removed by detuning the incident beam intensity to 60% of the maximum intensity. Three ionization chambers filled with He and N2 gases were used to record the intensity of the incident and of the transmitted X-rays. The studied materials are placed between the first and the second ionization chamber, while a reference foil (Mn) for energy calibration was placed between the second and the third ionization chamber. Under stationary conditions, extended X-ray absorption fine-structure (EXAFS) measurements were performed at the Mn K-edge in the step scanning mode.57a In the present case, fluorescence data were used for the investigation.
The program Athena was used to identify the location of the absorption edge (E0), to fit the pre- and post-edge backgrounds, and hence to obtain the normalized absorbance w as a function of the modulus of the photoelectron wavevector.57a,b The fit was carried out using ARTEMIS software in the k range of 2–9 Å. Selfabsorption correction was applied to the EXAFS data in k-space. The EXAFS data are Fourier-transformed to R-space to investigate the atomic structure and the relative bond lengths with respect to the absorbing atoms. The theoretical structure for the reference oxides was generated using the ATOM software.57a–c In the fit values of the coordination numbers (N), bond lengths (Ri) and Debye–Waller (s2) factors are kept free. The parameter eo, which is a correction to the edge energy, was free to vary in all fitting procedures. The errors in the fit parameters of the Ri and the s 2 values were obtained from 90% of the goodness-of-fit factor as calculated in the IFEFFIT software.

sections.heading: Fluorescence spectroscopy
sections.text: Poly-L-tyrosine or 1 dissolved/suspended in water was added to a mixture of 5 mL acetonitrile and 15.0 mL water. 2.0 g of imidazole was added to 25 mL of water and used as a titrant for the initially prepared nanocomposite of poly-L-tyrosine or 1 (50 mL imidazole in 15 steps). For this analyte the fluorescence emission spectra were recorded.

sections.heading: SEM/TEM studies
sections.text:
We used two different ratios of poly-L-tyrosine (PTyr) to nanosized Mn oxide to obtain material 1 and then imidazole was added as a model of histidine, inspired by the WOC in PSII. This organic matrix was selected as a model for YZ and D1-H190 near the manganese cluster in PSII. These organic matrices can also stabilize Mn(III) and may reduce the overpotential of Mn oxide for water oxidation. Mn oxide, 1, 2 and PTyr were characterized by TEM, SEM, UV-visible spectroscopy, and electrochemical analysis. TEM images of the nanocomposites of PTyr, 1, and 2 are shown in Fig. 1, which revealed the Mn oxide nanoparticles dispersed in the poly-L-tyrosine matrix. The HRTEM images of the 1 and 2 nanocomposites show that they are amorphous and no crystalline phase attributable to Mn oxide or poly-L-tyrosine was observed.
The morphologies of the tested nanocomposites were analyzed with scanning electron microscopy (Fig. 2). The SEM images of Mn

sections.heading: UV-Vis spectra
sections.text:
As illustrated in Fig. 3, the 1 and 2 materials showed a peak at B400–550 nm with the peak position at about 450 nm in the UV-visible spectra, attributed to Mn oxide embedded in the poly-L-tyrosine matrix. The peak is attributed to a transition between the valence and conduction bands comprising an excitation from an O2p to Mn3d orbital but with some Mn3d
to Mn3d character. The O contribution was greater for the valence band, whereas Mn3d states predominated in the conduction band.58 Poly-L-tyrosine showed no broad peaks in the B400–550 nm range. The grey area corresponds to the absorption bands expected for Mn oxide.

sections.heading: XANES/EXAFS spectra
sections.text:
X-ray Absorption Near Edge Structure (XANES) and Extended X-Ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS) spectra provide a useful description of the electronic structure of materials. Fig. 4 shows the normalized (a) and first derivative (b) XANES spectra of 2 and Mn oxide53d along with the reference oxides MnO(II), Mn2O3(III), and MnO2(IV). The main edge energies of MnO, Mn2O3 and MnO2 are at 6544.4 0.6, 6548.3 0.6 and 6551.73 eV, respectively. The main edge of 2 overlaps with that of MnO2 and the corresponding energy value is 6551.33 eV for the layered Mn oxide. Thus, the valence state of Mn ions in 2 is +4. In the layered Mn oxide phase, the Mn valence state appears to be slightly reduced to +3.8.53d The first derivative XANES spectra for 2 and the layered Mn oxide are shown in Fig. 4b.

The collated k3w(k) and the Fourier transform of the EXAFS spectra are shown in Fig. 5. The k oscillations for 2 showed almost the same behavior as that of MnO2. This revealed that the Mn atom coordination sphere in 2 is analogous to that in MnO2. It is clear from the Fourier transform of these spectra that the Mn–O distance in 2 is similar to that in MnO2. However, the Mn Mn bond-distance is slightly decreased compared to that in MnO2 (Fig. 5(b)). To get quantitative information about the bond length, the EXAFS spectra of these materials, along with MnO2, were simulated and the results obtained from the simulation are collected in Table 1. The Mn atom coordination number in 2 is around three.
Simulated Fourier transform spectra of these materials are shown in Fig. 6. It is clear that a major change is observed in the Mn Mn distance. The Mn–O distances for MnO2, layered Mn oxide and 2 are shown in Table 1. The Mn–O bond lengths remain the same within experimental error. Fig. 6 shows the proposed structure of the catalytically active part in 2.

sections.heading: Cyclic voltammetry
sections.text:

electrode and the Ag/AgCl electrode as the reference should be discussed.50e
For MnO two oxidation peaks are observed at 0.3–0.45 V (broad peak) and another peak is found at more than 1.0 V in comparison to the Mn(II) to Mn(III) oxidation and the leaked Mn(II) ions to Mn(IV) oxidation peak, respectively.

For Mn3O4 two oxidation peaks are observed at 0.36–0.56 (broad peak) and B1.0 V which is attributed to the Mn(II) to Mn(III) and Mn(II) to Mn(IV) oxidation peaks, respectively.
For Mn2O3 one oxidation peak is observed at 0.85 V and attributed to the Mn(III) to Mn(IV) oxidation.
For MnO2 one oxidation peak is observed at 0.86 V and attributed to the Mn(III) to Mn(IV) oxidation.
For the layered Mn oxide a broad peak within the 0.4–0.9 V region was observed, which is related to the Mn(II) to Mn(III) and Mn(III) to Mn(IV) oxidation processes. Thus, in some cases, the separate redox transitions are not clearly resolved.
These data comprise a roadmap useful to explain the peaks observed in cyclic voltammograms recorded for different nanocomposites containing Mn oxides.
The cyclic voltammogram for aqueous phenols on the FTO electrodes indicates an oxidation peak in the region of B1.0 V under various conditions.62 The peaks in the cyclic voltammograms (CVs) for these compounds were not clearly observed (Fig. S9, ESI†). Mn oxide showed one oxidation peak at 0.7–0.8 V attributable to the Mn(III) to Mn(IV) oxidation process. The peak at 1.0 V is usually attributed to the leaked Mn(II) ions to Mn(IV) oxidation. Thus, the oxide contains Mn(III) and Mn(IV). Disproportionation of Mn(III) may also lead to Mn(II) formation. Other compounds showed no clear peaks in their cyclic voltammograms.
In order to obtain more distinct peaks, a linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) method was used to study these compounds (Fig. 7a). As shown with LSV, the oxidation peak for the Mn(III)/ Mn(IV) couple is clearly observed for 1 at 0.8–1.0 V. However, the oxidation peaks for the phenoxyl/phenol couple in PTyr were not observed at 0.8 V.63 LSV results showed that the onset of water oxidation for the nanocomposite 2 is at 250 mV lower than that for PTyr (Fig. 7a). The experiment showed that very small amounts of Mn oxide in combination with PTyr led to an increase in water-oxidizing activity. We relate the high activity of this nanocomposite to both interaction of the Mn oxide with the organic matrix53,54,56 and nanodispersion of Mn oxide.
Fig. 7b and c show the SWV diagrams for 1, 2 and PTyr at different frequencies. Square wave voltammetry (SWV) is a very useful method to study low amounts of Mn oxide.
Under the reported conditions both 1 and 2 showed two oxidation peaks at 0.4 and B0.7 V related to the Mn(II) to Mn(III) and Mn(III) to Mn(IV) oxidation processes, respectively. These peaks are very similar to the oxidation peaks observed for Mn(IV) oxides.
Alternating current voltammetry (ACV) is a good method to study redox-active ions. The ACV increases sensitivity and reveals important mechanistic and kinetic information compared with other voltammetric techniques. As shown in Fig. 8, PTyr shows a few peaks at 0–1.2 V. Such complicated electrochemical profiles were reported for phenols.62 Nanolayered Mn oxide shows a broad peak at 0.2–1.2 V, which is attributed to the Mn(II) to Mn(III), Mn(III) to Mn(IV) and Mn(II) to Mn(IV) oxidation processes. Compared to the ACV of the Mn oxide, 1 indicates one oxidation peak at 0.6 V attributed to the oxidation of Mn(III) to Mn(IV). Another peak at 1.0 V is attributed to the Mn(II) to Mn(IV) oxidation. The changes in ACVs for Mn oxide and 1 are attributed to the polymer matrix, which stabilizes the high oxidation states of the Mn ions.

In the next step, we used a setup to measure oxygen evolution coupled to CV (scan rate: 0.0022 V s 1). Oxygen evolution for FTO without any catalyst was not observed (Fig. 9a). The experiment showed that oxygen evolution for Mn oxide not embedded in a matrix polymer started at 1.5 V (Fig. 9b). However, for 2 oxygen evolution was observed at B0.6 V (Fig. 9d), which most probably is related to the effect of the polymer on the stability of Mn(III).51–56 The amounts of evolved oxygen, in contrast to the onset of the potential of water oxidation, are not similar in 1, 2 and Mn oxide because the amounts of Mn ions are completely different in these three samples.
As we observed in electrochemical water oxidation, 2 is clearly different from 1. We suggest that lower amounts of nanosized Mn oxide in 2 and the higher degree of oxide dispersion cause these differences.

sections.heading: Fluorescence spectroscopy
sections.text:
Fluorescence spectroscopy is a potent technique that has been used to study the interactions between biomolecules and ligands. Valuable parameters, such as the binding constants, binding site characteristics and the interaction distances may be obtained using this technique.64,65 One of the processes that has been widely investigated using this technique is photosynthesis. Fluorescence has an important role in the understanding of the fundamental biochemical mechanisms, the reaction of plants to environmental change, genetic variation and ecological diversity.66
Thus, measurements of Chl a fluorescence transients are applied as a non-invasive tool for monitoring the activity of the photosynthetic systems.67,68 This is one of the most usual techniques used in plant physiology studies because the user can get detailed information on the state of PSII at relatively low cost.66 Chl a is the selected key molecule in the photosynthesis process.69,70 Chl a takes part in photon harvesting, in the transfer of excitation energy, in photochemical trapping, and also in the ground-state electron transfers. As its characteristic absorption and fluorescence properties are in the 400–750 nm part of the electromagnetic spectrum, Chl a has different functional roles in the protein complexes of PSI and of PSII.69 In the photosynthesis process, a photon absorbed by an antenna Chl molecule of PSII can excite an electron. The excited electron usually can return to the ground state and produce heat or Chl a fluorescence.71–73
The excited electron may be transmitted to P680 (Chl molecule of the PSII reaction center) and thus excite it. The excited electron on P680* (excited P680) will be further transmitted by the PSII electron transport chain that contains pheophytin (Pheo), plastoquinone A (QA), plastoquinone B (QB) etc. Then it will be applied for absorption of CO2 to generate chemical energy.
73,74 When P680* transfers its electron to Pheo, Pheo is reduced to negative Pheo (Pheo ) and P680 is oxidized. At the same time, P680+ quickly accepts a new electron that is produced from water and becomes P680 that is ready to receive photon energy from the PSII antenna Chl molecules. P680* may come back to the ground state and emit Chl fluorescence but the emission is partial in comparison with the emission from the antenna Chl molecules.73–78
Excitation–emission matrix (EEM) fluorescence spectroscopy, which was introduced by Christian and co-workers and applied for analyzing multi-component systems,79 is a common method to survey the structural changes and optical characteristics of chromophores because it delivers fast results, causes no damage to the measured samples and displays a high sensitivity.80–84 One of the chemometrics methods that has been successfully applied to analyze multi-component systems displaying significant spectral overlap is the MCR-ALS technique.79,85–87 Analyses of the EEM datasets by the MCR-ALS method need unfolding of the three-way array, sample emission excitation, along with the sample mode. The MCR-ALS models are usually fitted under the constraints on both the matrices C and S.79 One of these constraints is non-negativity as used herein. In this study, we investigated the interaction of poly-L-tyrosine and poly-L-tyrosine/ Mn oxide in the presence of different concentrations of imidazole to simulate the involved hydrogen bonds. We used excitation– emission matrix (EEM) fluorescence spectroscopy and the MCRALS as methods. As the fluorescence excitation–emission (EEM) spectra of poly-L-tyrosine/Mn oxide and poly-L-tyrosine are affected by imidazole (Fig. S10 and S12, lmaxem = 400 nm, ESI†), the adduct formation process can be followed by recording the fluorescence EEM spectra of imidazole. Firstly, the fluorescence spectra of poly-Ltyrosine/Mn oxide and of poly-L-tyrosine were individually recorded after 15 titration steps with imidazole. EEM data modeling was performed in a Matlab 7.8.0.347 environment (Fig. S13, ESI†).
Before the analysis, the Rayleigh scattering was eliminated and thus two arrays of 19 (lex) 121 (lem) 15 (steps of titration) were obtained. The data array was unfolded to a matrix with the size of 2299 (lex lem) 15 (steps of titration) and analysed using the MCR-ALS method. Emission spectra for pure imidazole are shown in Fig. S14 (ESI†).

sections.heading: Poly-L-tyrosine/Mn-imidazole interaction
sections.text:
The blue profile (lmaxex-em = 300 nm) is related to poly-L-tyrosine/Mn oxide. It shows intense fluorescence which gradually reduces in intensity with the addition of imidazole (Fig. 10). Then this fluorescence intensity decreases in the course of six titrations to reach zero with the formation of the second poly-L-tyrosine/Mn oxide-imidazole adduct (MLn, M = poly-L-tyrosine/Mn oxide and L = imidazole). The red profile in Fig. 10 is related to the second poly-L-tyrosine-imidazole adduct (lmaxex-em = 380 nm). The green profile (lmaxex-em = 380 nm) corresponds to the formation of the first
adduct (MLm). The fluorescence intensity is initially low and then slowly increases upon addition of imidazole until step three of the titration of the reaction medium but after that the fluorescence intensity is reduced with low slope due to consumption of the adduct and the formation of the second poly-L-tyrosineimidazole adduct (MLn). We used the m and n letters to denote the number of ligands in the adducts because the ratio of imidazole/poly-L-tyrosine is not clear.
In the step of the titration, the fluorescence intensity of the first adduct (MLm) is suddenly reduced to zero. Also, at the same moment, the fluorescence intensity of the second adduct (MLn) increases but with a negative slope. As shown in Fig. 10a, the excitation–emission spectra are similar for both adducts.

sections.heading: Poly-L-tyrosine-imidazole interaction
sections.text:
The blue profile in Fig. 11a (lmaxex-em = 370 nm) is the estimated excitation–emission spectrum of poly-L-tyrosine. As it is shown in Fig. 11b, at first when no imidazole is added, the poly-Ltyrosine displays a high fluorescence. Poly-L-tyrosine concentration gradually reduces with the addition of imidazole, then its value in step six of the titration drops to zero and so, in the same step, the second poly-L-tyrosine-imidazole adduct (MLq) is formed. The red profiles in Fig. 11a and b are shown for the resulting spectrum and the concentration of MLq (l max ex-em = 375 nm).
The green profiles in Fig. 11 represent the formation of the first adduct of poly-L-tyrosine with imidazole (MLp). The spectrum of MLp with l max ex-em = 375 nm is shown in Fig. 11b. The fluorescence intensity of MLp is initially low and then gradually increases upon addition of imidazole until step five of the titration. Subsequently, suddenly the concentration of MLq and its fluorescence intensity are reduced. This is due to conversion of MLp to MLq which results in a higher slope in the spectrum than recorded upon its formation in the poly-L-tyrosine-imidazole system. Fig. 11a shows the

Although the third resolved spectral profile is very similar to the one for imidazole, it is most likely that this is due to the formation of a second adduct (Scheme 3). This is because at the same time the ‘‘green’’ profile of the first adduct disappears and this indicates the formation of a second adduct.
Comparison of the red concentration profile in Fig. 11 and the red concentration profile in Fig. 10 shows the different tendencies for the formation of the second adduct from the first adduct as imidazole is added to poly-L-tyrosine. In the case of poly-L-tyrosine the first adduct converts to the second adduct faster than for poly-L-tyrosine-Mn oxide. Secondary formation and primary conversion of the first adduct in the absence of Mn show the effect of Mn on the stability of the first adduct. The dominant ‘‘green’’ concentration profile for the first adduct of poly-L-tyrosine/Mn oxide (Fig. 10b) is due to the possible interactions of manganese with imidazole groups that may be more complicated than the interaction with pure poly-L-tyrosine. Actually, the weak interactions are formed when the concentration of imidazole is relatively high and the spectrum changes to form a new adduct at even higher concentrations of imidazole.
In 1 and 2, in contrast to PSII, the particles of Mn oxides are not located on a particular site but distributed in the organic matrix.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
A polypeptide around nanosized Mn oxide is an idea to design new catalysts with high active site densities, compared with natural enzymes. We studied poly-L-tyrosine/Mn oxide nanocomposites as a model for the water-oxidizing catalyst in PSII. The nanocomposites were obtained with simple methods. TEM images of the nanocomposites of PTyr and the studied nanocomposites showed that Mn oxide nanoparticles were dispersed in a poly-L-tyrosine matrix. HRTEM images of the studied nanocomposites showed no crystalline phase attributed to Mn oxide or poly-L-tyrosine. Mn oxide appears to be amorphous on these images. SEM images of PTyr showed irregular particles (diameter: 200–600 nm). Similar morphologies were observed for the studied nanocomposites with Mn oxide, which proved that the mixing procedure has no significant effect on the morphology of PTyr. The nanocomposite showed a band at
B400–550 nm in its UV-visible spectra, which is explained in terms of the presence of Mn oxide formation in the poly-Ltyrosine matrix. The electrochemical methods showed the peaks attributed to Mn oxide and indicated a decrease in the onset of the potential of water oxidation. In the next step, the interaction of the nanocomposite and imidazole as a model for YZ and D1-His190 in PSII was studied with fluorescence spectroscopy, which indicates the interactions between the nanocomposite and imidazole.
To design an ‘‘artificial enzyme’’ with high active site densities to be used in industry, such questions as those listed below must be addressed:
– Can this strategy be used to design an efficient catalyst at higher potentials? If yes, what is a stable organic matrix under these conditions?
– What is a good sequence of amino acids around Mn oxide to significantly increase the water-oxidizing activities of Mn oxides?
– Is it useful to design sequences of amino acids around other metal oxides or other water-oxidizing catalysts to increase their catalytic activity toward water oxidation?
– How can we design channels or groups to efficiently remove protons near the catalyst?
– How can we arrange the active sites to create super-catalysts?

author: H.K. Lichtenthaler

metadata.abstractText: Herein we report on a poly-peptide/Mn oxide nanocomposite as a model for the water-oxidizing catalyst in Photosystem II. The material is obtained by the reaction of poly-L-tyrosine, Mn(OAc)2 4H2O and KMnO4. HRTEM images of the nanocomposite indicate the presence of nanoparticles dispersed in a poly-Ltyrosine matrix with no crystalline phases. A broad peak at B400–550 nm in the UV-visible spectrum is related to Mn oxide formation. X-ray absorption studies suggest that the Mn atoms are in the oxidation state of +IV and a coordination number of around three was obtained for Mn in the structure. The wateroxidizing activity of the material under electrochemical conditions was also investigated. Electrochemical experiments proved the presence of Mn(IV) oxide. Determination of oxygen coupled to electrochemistry revealed the role of poly-L-tyrosine in decreasing the overpotential for water oxidation. In the next step, the interaction of the nanocomposite and imidazole as a model for the tyrosine 161 and histidine 190 residues in Photosystem II was studied with fluorescence spectroscopy using the multivariate curve resolution-alternating least squares method.
